articles.headline: SoFi, an Online Lender, Is Looking for a Relationship
articles.snippet: Social Finance Inc., or SoFi, takes a different approach to consumer lending, one that includes holding singles and networking events.
articles.abstract: Social Finance Inc., or SoFi, takes a different approach to consumer lending, one that includes holding singles and networking events.
articles.lead_paragraph: SAN FRANCISCO — Alyson Casey recently received an invitation to a singles event in Manhattan from a start-up. But it didn’t come from a dating service. It came from the company that had recently refinanced her student loan: SoFi.

articles.headline: In Push for G.M.O.s, China Battles Fears of 8-Legged Chickens
articles.snippet: A Chinese firm’s $43 billion effort to buy Syngenta could upend the industry, but it faces widespread fears at home over modified food.
articles.abstract: A Chinese firm’s $43 billion effort to buy Syngenta could upend the industry, but it faces widespread fears at home over modified food.
articles.lead_paragraph: HONG KONG — For many in China, the term “genetically modified food” evokes nightmares: poisoned seeds, contaminated fields, apocryphal images of eight-legged chickens.
articles.byline: By Amie Tsang and Cao Li

articles.headline: Trove of Stolen Data Is Said to Include Top-Secret U.S. Hacking Tools
articles.snippet: Investigators found that stolen documents in the possession of Harold T. Martin III included top-secret N.S.A. hacking tools that two months ago were offered for sale on the internet.
articles.abstract: Investigators found that stolen documents in the possession of Harold T. Martin III included top-secret N.S.A. hacking tools that two months ago were offered for sale on the internet.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Investigators pursuing what they believe to be the largest case of mishandling classified documents in United States history have found that the huge trove of stolen documents in the possession of a National Security Agency contractor included top-secret N.S.A. hacking tools that two months ago were offered for sale on the internet.
articles.byline: By Scott Shane, Matt Apuzzo and Jo Becker

articles.headline: A.G. Sulzberger: Leading Change at The New York Times as Journalism Evolves
articles.snippet: Mr. Sulzberger, who was named The Times’s deputy publisher, is the author of a report calling for sweeping changes and a digital future for the paper.
articles.abstract: Mr. Sulzberger, who was named The Times’s deputy publisher, is the author of a report calling for sweeping changes and a digital future for the paper.
articles.lead_paragraph: [Update: A.G. Sulzberger will take over as publisher of The New York Times on Jan. 1, The Times announced on Dec. 14, 2017.]

articles.headline: Donald Trump Won’t Say if He’ll Accept Result of Election
articles.snippet: “I will keep you in suspense,” Donald Trump said at a debate that began cordially but turned caustic. Hillary Clinton replied that his statement was “horrifying.”
articles.abstract: “I will keep you in suspense,” Donald Trump said at a debate that began cordially but turned caustic. Hillary Clinton replied that his statement was “horrifying.”
articles.lead_paragraph: In a remarkable statement that seemed to cast doubt on American democracy, Donald J. Trump said Wednesday that he might not accept the results of next month’s election if he felt it was rigged against him — a stand that Hillary Clinton blasted as “horrifying” at their final and caustic debate on Wednesday.
articles.byline: By Patrick Healy and Jonathan Martin

articles.headline: Hillary Clinton, Mocking and Taunting in Debate, Turns the Tormentor
articles.snippet: In the third and final debate, Mrs. Clinton outmaneuvered Donald J. Trump with a surprising new approach: his.
articles.abstract: In the third and final debate, Mrs. Clinton outmaneuvered Donald J. Trump with a surprising new approach: his.
articles.lead_paragraph: She mansplained him. “Let me translate that if I can,” Hillary Clinton said dryly after Donald J. Trump talked up his tax plan.
articles.byline: By Amy Chozick and Michael Barbaro

articles.headline: Kurds, Heading Into the Teeth of ISIS, Open a New Front
articles.snippet: A U.S. soldier is among the dead in an expansion of the effort to retake Mosul, including moves by Iraqi forces and a new, village-by-village Kurdish thrust from the north.
articles.abstract: A U.S. soldier is among the dead in an expansion of the effort to retake Mosul, including moves by Iraqi forces and a new, village-by-village Kurdish thrust from the north.
articles.lead_paragraph: Mr. Gordon, a New York Times military correspondent, is with Kurdish pesh merga forces on the northern approach to Mosul.

articles.headline: He Stars in a Spanish-Language Soap. Why Is He Driving for Uber?
articles.snippet: Many working telenovela actors who shoot their shows in Miami struggle to make ends meet, because they are not protected by the television industry’s union.
articles.abstract: Many working telenovela actors who shoot their shows in Miami struggle to make ends meet, because they are not protected by the television industry’s union.
articles.lead_paragraph: MIAMI — It was a scene right out of a juicy telenovela, one of those Spanish-language soap operas that unfold one betrayal and love affair at a time on television screens all over the world.

articles.headline: Thousands of Men to Be Pardoned for Gay Sex, Once a Crime in Britain
articles.snippet: The proposed Turing Law, named for the mathematician who was prosecuted in the 1950s, provides for posthumous pardons and allows men who are still alive to apply for pardons.
articles.abstract: The proposed Turing Law, named for the mathematician who was prosecuted in the 1950s, provides for posthumous pardons and allows men who are still alive to apply for pardons.
articles.lead_paragraph: LONDON — The men were convicted — tens of thousands of them — of crimes like buggery, gross indecency and loitering with intent. They had been arrested in bars, coffee houses and public bathrooms, and sometimes in the privacy of their homes and with their partners. In many cases, their only offense was seeking intimacy with another man.

articles.headline: Donald Trump Says He Will Accept Election Outcome (‘if I Win’)
articles.snippet: “Of course I would accept a clear election result, but I would also reserve my right to contest or file a legal challenge in the case of a questionable result,” Mr. Trump said.
articles.abstract: “Of course I would accept a clear election result, but I would also reserve my right to contest or file a legal challenge in the case of a questionable result,” Mr. Trump said.
articles.lead_paragraph: Donald J. Trump insisted on Thursday that he would not cede the right to contest the outcome of the presidential election, even as Democrats and Republicans expressed concern that his position threatened to upend America’s tradition of peaceful power transfers. But in a small gesture of civility, he suggested that he would not dispute the result if the outcome of the race was clear.
articles.byline: By Alan Rappeport and Alexander Burns

articles.headline: How Much Graduates Earn Drives More College Rankings
articles.snippet: The purpose of education is to stretch and elevate young minds, right? Now some rankings are including future earnings in their calculations.
articles.abstract: The purpose of education is to stretch and elevate young minds, right? Now some rankings are including future earnings in their calculations.
articles.lead_paragraph: PayScale introduced its first college salary report in 2008, and the College Scorecard from the federal government followed last year, ushering an elephant into the hallowed halls of college admissions: What do the schools’ graduates actually earn?

articles.headline: ‘Lions Hunting Zebras’: Ex-Wells Fargo Bankers Describe Abuses
articles.snippet: In legal filings and statements, former employees of the bank said immigrants, older adults, college students and Native Americans were targeted for fake accounts.
articles.abstract: In legal filings and statements, former employees of the bank said immigrants, older adults, college students and Native Americans were targeted for fake accounts.
articles.lead_paragraph: Mexican immigrants who speak little English. Older adults with memory problems. College students opening their first bank accounts. Small-business owners with several lines of credit.
